content:
(iii) There is a repulsive force when north poles ( or south poles ) of two magnets are brought close together.

Conversely, there is an attractive force between the north pole of one magnet and the south pole of the other.

(iv) We cannot isolate the north, or south pole of a magnet.

If a bar magnet is broken into two halves, we get two similar bar magnets with somewhat weaker properties.

Unlike electric charges, isolated magnetic north and south poles known as magnetic monopoles do not exist.
summary: The text discusses the attraction and repulsion of magnet poles and the absence of magnetic monopoles.
hypothetical_questions: What happens when north and south poles of two magnets come close together?
What is the difference in the rod magnet's strength when split into two parts?
Are isolated magnetic north or south poles possible?
